results.title: Desert people
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Scenes typical of the daily life of the Pintubi tribe in the Western Desert cultural area, showing two families: the first was filmed as they were found living in desert conditions, the second had recently settled at Warburton Mission and demonstrated how they had lived a few months earlier. (A shorter version of People of the Australian Western Desert, Pts. l, 2 and 4.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Australian Aborigines: cooking
results.creator_credit: A.P. Elkin and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Modern social studies”.
Taken during the University of Sydney’s expedition to Arnhem Land, this film shows the traditional methods the local people use to cook food.

results.title: Camels and the Pitjantjara
results.creator_credit: Roger Sandall, Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Shows the daily life of nomadic Central Australians of the Pitjantjara tribe who have acquired camels, guns and other modern equipment. Shows the capture of a wild camel and travels in the MacDonnell Range; hunting rabbits and living off the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Sandall, Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: A Calendar of dreamings: Aboriginal artists of Central Australia
results.brief_description: This film depicts the mythology of First Nations people in the western McDonald Range area of Central Australia with specific reference to three tribal groups. It deals with ‘water dreaming’ as well as various myths and legends related to the present situation. The film incorporates approximately 44 paintings by Central Australia First Nations people using an ancient technique known as sand painting. A study of the meanings of the symbols and signs used in some paintings. Legends of the Dreamtime are passed down to the younger member by their elders in ritual ceremonies. Narrated by John Bell, edited by Phil Noyce.

results.title: Brown men and red sand
results.creator_credit: C Mountford and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau
results.brief_description: This film is part of the original silent film record of C.P. Mountford’s Central Australian journey with a group of desert First Nations people. From the original footage the two popular sound films, “Walkabout” and “Tjurunga”, were compiled. “Brown men and red sand” (if projected at silent speed) shows movement more naturally than in the sound films, where the movements look jerky (especially in the sequences dealing with ceremonies and dances).
results.creator_credit_for_label: C Mountford and South Australian Government Tourist Bureau

results.title: Beyond hell's gate
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Peter Johnson, Film Australia, Nomad Films and Satonyx Films
results.brief_description: Three trailbike riders retrace the route that led 15,000 Chinese and 1,500 Europeans from Cooktown through Hell’s Gate to the Palmer Goldfields of Northern Queensland. Partly dramatised, it recounts the coming of the Chinese, conflicts with local people and shows remnants of Maytown, the old mining settlement of Christie Palmerston, a legendary figure of the period.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Roberts, Peter Johnson, Film Australia, Nomad Films and Satonyx Films

results.title: Australian Aborigines: art, life and religion
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Modern social studies”.
A portrayal of some aspects of Australian First Nations people’s ceremonial practices. The spiritual significance of body paintings, dancing and singing is explained. Taken during the University of Sydney’s expedition to Arnhem Land, led by Professor A. P. Elkin in 1952.

results.title: Gurrawilla
results.creator_credit: Chelsea Studios for the Education Department of Victoria, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alan Marshall: author and man”.
At one time, Marshall lived with First Nations people in Arnhem Land, and he tells us how he became known as ‘Gurrawilla’. He also describes in a light-hearted manner tales of his childhood.

results.title: Aborigines of the Sea Coast
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford, Dept of Interior and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film records the 1948 expedition to Arnhem Land sponsored by the National Geographical Society and the Smithsonian Institution. It shows the life of First Nations people of the sea coast at Yirrkala in the north-eastern corner of Arnhem Land. Demonstrates how, as children, they learn to handle canoes made from bark and as adults how they use them for fishing and hunting turtle. Shows how the canoes are made by stripping bark from a tree. The women of the tribe do the camp chores, collect firewood, make string bags, hunt goannas, and search for food plants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles P. Mountford, Dept of Interior and Australian National Film Board
